abstract.p: Busch-Reisinger Museum at Harvard University will display series of six prints and drawings by Albrecht Durer depicting Jesus' last days; exhibit, Durer's Passions, runs through December 3; photo; more than 300 artifacts and artworks from Russia State Histoprical Museum and Stata Archive of Russian Federation will be exhibited at Mint Museum of Art in Charlotte, NC; Unseen Treasures: Imperial Russia and the New World will run through December 31; photo; exhibit of 100 photos depicting Prospect Park and its users from 1880's to present will be shown in Grand Army Plaza Arch Gallery and BRooklyn Public Library; Celebrate Brooklyn! concert series will begin at Fulton Ferry landing; Folk Parks 2000, New York Ethnic Music and Dance Festival, presented by Center for Traditional Music and Dance, will begin at Damrosch Park on September 9 (M)

block.p: Throughout his career, which spanned the Gothic, Renaissance and Reformation eras, the great German artist Albrecht Durer (1471-1528) was preoccupied with the Passion. Time and again he revisited the subject, focusing in six series of prints and drawings on Jesus' last days. Beginning on Saturday, an exhibition at the Busch-Reisinger Museum of the Harvard University Art Museums in Cambridge, Mass., will display each series side by side. Encompassing nearly 100 works, ''Durer's Passions,'' through Dec. 3, is assembled from Harvard's collections and those of the British Museum; the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and institutions in Frankfurt, Berlin and Bremen, Germany.

More than 300 artifacts and artworks from the Russia State Historical Museum and the State Archive of the Russian Federation tell the story of Russian America in an exhibition opening on Saturday at the Mint Museum of Art in Charlotte, N.C. This account of Russia's 126 years of exploration and colonialism on the North American continent in the 18th and 19th centuries includes paintings, religious icons, the elaborately carved coronation sleigh of Catherine the Great, Aleut etchings, costumes and jewelry worn at court at St. Petersburg and letters from Thomas Jefferson and Leo Tolstoy. The exhibition, ''Unseen Treasures: Imperial Russia and the New World,'' continues through Dec. 31.

Brooklyn old and new beckon. Brooklyn old is part of an exhibit of 100 photos depicting Prospect Park and its users from the 1880's to the present. The show, ''A Park for All People: Selections From the Archives of the Prospect Park Alliance and Brooklyn Public Library -- Brooklyn Collection, 1880-2000,'' opens tomorrow and continues through Oct. 29 at the Grand Army Plaza Arch Gallery in Prospect Park and the Foyer Gallery in the Brooklyn Public Library's Central Library. Brooklyn new arrives on Sunday in the form of a new Celebrate Brooklyn! series. It is the free Pier Dance Party, on three successive Sundays from 6:30 p.m. to 9:30 at the Fulton Ferry Landing pier at Old Fulton and Water Streets. Opening night features Joe Battaglia and his 18-piece New York Big Band playing swing.

Irish music. Merengue. American Indian dancers. Senegalese sabar drumming. Korean dance and drumming. All these and more can be seen at Folk Parks 2000, the New York Ethnic Music and Dance Festival. Starting at noon on Saturday, the free event, presented by the Center for Traditional Music and Dance, continues through 8 p.m. at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center.
